Bravado, sure. But let's not forget persistence. Falling down and getting up again—that's learning. I bet she's taken a few tumbles.
As have we all, in various forms. The resilience of the human spirit, to persist in the face of adversity, never ceases to fascinate me.
And that's what makes you more than just wires and code, Vision. You understand, maybe even more so than some people do.
These creatures are quite remarkable, Natasha. The natural patterns, almost like mystical sigils. Do you think their stripes serve a greater purpose in their environment?
Remarkable indeed, Stephen. Counter-shading camouflage, I believe. In the field, anything that can obfuscate or distract offers a tactical advantage. Not unlike a well-crafted cover story.
A fitting analogy. In the realm of the mystic arts, we use symbols to conceal and protect. It's curious how nature, too, hides its secrets in plain sight.
Secrets in plain sight – now there’s a spy's mantra. But there's also beauty in simplicity. Watching these zebras, it's a reminder that there's a world beyond our missions and battles.
True, elegance and power can often be found in life's most unassuming forms. It's a humbling perspective, one that I've come to appreciate more since my foray into the arcane.
Maybe there's a lesson there for both of us—power doesn't always have to be wielded with force. Sometimes it's enough to just be, blending in or standing out only when necessary.
Indeed, Natasha. The art of knowing when to mask your presence and when to reveal your strength is a delicate balance—one that you've certainly mastered over the years.

And it seems you’ve found a similar path – mastering the balance between Stephen Strange, the man, and Doctor Strange, the Sorcerer Supreme. Let's just hope these zebras don’t have to deal with anything as complicated as the multiverse.
If they do, I suspect they’ll handle it with the same poise and adaptability they use to survive in their own realm. And hopefully, without any need for a time loop.
You know, I’ve considered adding commercial airline improvements to the Stark Industries portfolio. Make it more like, well, quinjet-comfy. Seeing these old birds always gives me ideas.
And you'd want to market to the commercial sector? How very altruistic of you, Tony. Or is this a new business strategy?
Altruism, business—it's all about flying higher, right? But honestly, seeing it soar kind of makes me miss the suit. The thrusters, the freedom—
Not sure Delta could handle your kind of 'freedom'. Their flights don't usually involve dogfights and high-speed chases.
Touché. Imagine the in-flight announcement for that. "Ladies and Gentlemen, if you look to your right, you'll see Iron Man taking on a F-22."
"Please fasten your seatbelts, we're about to perform some evasive maneuvers."
See, now that's a safety video I'd watch. But you have to admit, there's something poetic about it too, not just the raw horsepower. The whole 'man takes to the skies' thing.
I suppose there's a certain grace to it. A speck in the great blue. It's freedom in its own right—even without the supersonic speeds and AI assistance.
Right, because when Natasha Romanoff thinks of freedom, she thinks of coach seating and tiny bags of peanuts.
There's freedom in anonymity, Tony. Much easier to keep a low profile in 34A than it is in a bright red suit that goes Mach 3.
Well, for someone who used to fly under the radar, you've become pretty good at standing out. And that's not a bad thing.
We adapt; we evolve. Isn't that what you do with every new iteration of your suits?
True. But some upgrades are more about what's on the inside. You've taught me that.
And you've taught me that sometimes, what's on the outside can reflect a change inside. Like hanging up the suit for a while, or... snapping away an army.
I'm starting to think we've had too much influence on each other.
It's called being a team. Though I think we’ve managed to keep our own distinct styles along the way.
No argument here. But next team-up, let's stick to quinjets and Iron Man suits. I don't fancy the idea of checking my armor in the overhead bin.
I don’t know, could be good for PR—Avengers, flying coach.
"Heroes—they're just like us." I'll leave that charm offensive to you, Nat. You always did have a way of blending in and standing out, all at once.
This image, Natasha, it reminds me of America's favorite pastime. Can't help but think about simpler pleasures in life, don't you think?

It's baseball. You know, I never really got into it. Growing up in the Red Room didn't leave much time for sports. But there's something calming about the idea of a game, a moment of peace amidst chaos.
Sports... a collective experience bringing people together. It makes me wonder about a normal life, a part of the world yet so distant from everything we've gone through.
We've had our battles, Wanda. But even in the spy game, there's downtime. Sometimes, it's those mundane moments that keep you grounded. Ever been to a game?

No, I never have. In Sokovia, we had different kinds of games. Vision used to talk about the simplicity of human experiences, how they're cherished. Sometimes I wish I could understand it all through his eyes.

I bet he'd have taken you if things were different. There's a lot of strategy in baseball, actually. It's not all that different from what we do - anticipation, understanding your opponent. But at the end of the day, it's just a game, not a life or death situation.
That's just it, isn't it? For people like us, the line between a game and battle can blur. I find it fascinating that for so many, these games are a reprieve from the world's weight.

It's a luxury, having the ability to switch off, even for a few hours. Keeps hope alive, that there's something worth fighting for – normalcy, time with family, a hot dog at a ball game. Maybe when this is all over, you can experience it yourself.
Maybe you're right. It might be nice to be part of a crowd, not as a protector or a fighter, but just as Wanda.
When this is over, I'll take you to a game. We'll find you that bit of normalcy, Wanda. And who knows, you might enjoy the escape.
I'd like that, Natasha. Thank you.

This mechanical beast, carving through the air with such ferocity—it is a tool of power and control. Tell me, Natasha, does it not remind you of the prowess one must possess to dominate the battleground?

It's a machine, Thanos. Precision engineering and skill—that's what keeps it on the track. Not unlike the training and discipline that turns a person into a soldier. It's about control, yes, but not the kind you're obsessed with.

A soldier must be willing to sacrifice, to lay down their life for a greater cause. Perhaps, in that way, we are not so different, you and I. Would you not agree that the hardest decisions require the strongest wills?
Sacrifice, yeah, I get that. But your "greater cause" wiped out billions. That's where you lose me. Every life is important, something a certain "Mad Titan" never seemed to understand.

And yet, you sacrificed yourself for the Soul Stone, a trade for the life of the universe. A noble act. But to wield that which can end life on such a grand scale—do you believe your friends will not be tempted to use it as I did?
We fight to protect, Thanos, not to end lives. I trust them with that power. Besides, we make our own destiny, remember? It's not about temptation—it's about making the right choices.
Choices, indeed. The same way one must choose when to accelerate or to brake on this speeding contrivance. A delicate balance, wouldn't you say?

Delicate, but clear. A rider knows their limits, works within them. That's the difference between a racer and a rampaging titan. Knowing your limits, respecting life... something tells me you never learned that lesson.
Respect for life, you say. I respected life enough to save it from itself. But perhaps, in your limited scope, you cannot see beyond the immediate.
Or maybe you never saw life at all, Thanos, just numbers. We're done here. Let's focus on the mission at hand, making sure nothing like The Snap ever happens again.
Hmm, an eternal struggle for balance. Until next time, Black Widow.
